instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
HEy I am working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power. So usb meter was sticking at 5v with 32amps when i started. Noticed corrosion on CB300 which is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. Removed that cap and now I get 20v (sometimes at 1.4 amps, sometimes at 14amps or sometimes at 5 amps.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> is missing

Do you think it is <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
You've said to get 20V at USB-C inputs now.
Each USB-C port has its VBUS line; you must check each port separately.
<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips should be good, if switch to 20V.
Check if all ports have the same behaviour.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
All ports have same behavior but anos at 5,47 which is a little high. let me give some more details

<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TA_VBUS</SIGNAL> 20v
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TA_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> 20v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TB_VBUS</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TB_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> missing

Could it be the B controller?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: nevermind only the A mesurements will be right as the side it is plugged in. dumb question

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: so essentially no <SIGNAL>PPDIN_G3H</SIGNAL> where do I look

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Please confirm, do you get 20V at USB-C voltmeter, but 0V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>???
That is impossible; it will imply no <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present, and <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips cannot switch to 20V.
Are you using original 87W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> shorted to ground. I see both run to <RESISTOR>R7030</RESISTOR> I believe. Don't have schematic on me. I will check it in the morning

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: So you have a short to ground at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
